message: Thanks! This is just what I needed!

@Anonymous: Since I wrote this blog post, I have heard other people state that their foreign keys were imported correctly as well. It did not work for me, but the db I have to work with is not well designed at all (e.g., most foreign "keys" are nullable text columns). I'll update the blog post.

There are several things that I canÂ´t understand.   

I'm able to "read" the associations via EF Designer import from database... All the relations appears right configured, and with the "Add foreign key properties" checked. So I think that I misundestand something in this article.
You can see a pile of SQLite related videos at [ YouTube ](http://www.youtube.com/user/Jaynonymous1) which show how to use and program against SQLite.

I'm not sure it is a good idea to handle transactions by yourself because you will be out of sync regarding the ObjetContext cache.  
make a saveChanges(), then rollback, then what ? Entities are still in the ObjectContext even they no longer exist in the db.

Thanks Stephen, you have saved me a lot of pain already.   

I've found Entity Framework 4 will pick up on Foreign Keys defined in databases created using SQLiteMaestro.  

Not sure but Core Data appears to have its own legacy FK mechanism which doesn't blend with EF.
It should be noted that the newest version of System.Data.SQLite is now at [http://system.data.sqlite.org/](http://system.data.sqlite.org/)
